TEXT.English: [H1]Jan Hus[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Priest, philosopher, reformer, and master at Charles University in Prague[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] c. 1369 - 1415[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Among the many, no doubt apocryphal, stories of Jan Hus's life is one that relates an incident in his youth, which foreshadowed his fate as a Christian martyr. According to the account, the youthful Hus was sitting beside a fire one winter evening reading about the martyrdom of St. Lawrence. Suddenly, he thrust his hand into the flames. When a fellow pupil pulled him away from the fire and questioned his intentions, Hus replied: "I was only trying what part of the tortures of this holy man I might be capable of enduring."What truth, if any, there is in the story cannot be determined. But what is historical fact is that on July 6, 1415, condemned as an arch-heretic by the Council of Constance and turned over to the state for execution, Jan Hus sang a hymn as the flames engulfed his body in a meadow just outside the city walls of Constance. Hus was charged with propagating the heretical teachings of the late 14th-century English reformer John Wycliffe, "the Morning Star of the Reformation," whose bones the Council of Constance ordered disinterred and burned. One hundred years later, Martin Luther was charged with heresy by the church hierarchy for espousing views associated with Hus and condemned as heresy by the Council of Constance. Therein lies the historical significance of Jan Hus. He was a vital link in the chain of reformers who sought to reform the late-medieval church, and whose efforts, often punctuated by martyrdom, culminated in the 16th-century Reformation.The period of the Renaissance church (roughly the mid-14th through 16th centuries) was, spiritually speaking, the bleakest chapter in Church history. In 1303, Pope Boniface VIII was taken captive by the French king Philip IV, and the papal court moved to Avignon in southern France. An attempt in 1378 to end the "Babylonian Captivity" and return the papal court to Rome led only to the election of two rival popes, one in Avignon and the other in Rome. Both were dominated by men who often made no pretense to spiritual interests. But as destructive as it was, the worldliness of the Renaissance popes did not damage the spiritual authority of the church nearly so much as the Great Schism, the scandal of two popes.According to the teachings of the medieval church, the pope, or bishop of Rome, was "the vicar of Christ, the successor to St. Peter, the keeper of the keys, the servus servorum Dei, the servant of the servants of God." How then could the authority of Christ be divided? Only one of the two popes could be the true successor of St. Peter according to apostolic succession. The other had to be an antipope. But which was the pope and which was the antipope? And were the sacraments, held to be necessary for the salvation of the individual, valid if performed under the authority of the antipope?It is within the context of this crisis of faith within the late-medieval church that the life of Jan Hus must be considered. But it also must be viewed against the backdrop of imperial politics within the Holy Roman Empire and the emergence of Bohemian (or Czech) nationalism. The two are so closely intertwined that they cannot be separated. The cause of religious reform in Bohemia at the turn of the 15th century was also the cry of Bohemian nationalism within the Holy Roman Empire.The exact date of Jan Hus's birth cannot be determined. It has been variously given as the year 1369, 1372, 1373 or 1375. Popular legend placed the exact date as July 6, 1369, but July 6 is believed to be nothing more than an imaginative analogy with the date of his martyrdom. In any event, he was born in Husinec (meaning "Goosetown") in southern Bohemia on the border of Bavaria.In his youth, Jan Hus was known simply as "Jan, son of Michael," since it was customary in Bohemia to identify a man by giving his Christian name and the name of his father. In the register of the University of Prague, he is inscribed as "Jan of Husinec," or "Jan from the village of Husinec." Between 1398 and 1400, he signed his name as "Jan Hus," or "Jan Hus of Husinec." After 1400, he always signed his name as simply "Jan Hus." Thus he derived his last name "Hus" from the name of his birthplace, and his actual family name is lost to history.Of Jan Hus's family even less is known. It is assumed that his parents were humble people of peasant background. Nothing is known of his father, who apparently died when Jan was very young. His mother was a very pious woman. A casual mention in one of his surviving letters leads scholars to assume that Jan Hus had brothers, but nothing is known of them or any possible sisters.Jan Hus received his "elementary" schooling in the Latin school of the nearby town of Prachatice. When 18 years old, he enrolled at the University of Prague. From then until his death in 1415, his life and fate were shaped by the political and religious struggles that characterized this divided university. In 1393 or 1394, he received his bachelor's degree, and by 1396, his master of arts. That same year, he became a member of the faculty of arts at the university. At first, he lectured on the philosophy of the ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle and the realist philosophy of John Wycliffe. While teaching, Hus also pursued theological studies and in 1404, he earned a bachelor of divinity degree. Three years later, he was in the process of earning his doctorate but never received it. Instead, he earned the martyr's crown.At what point in his life Jan Hus made the transition to a religious reformer is also unknown. He once commented that the reason he wanted to become a priest was "to secure a good livelihood and dress and be held in esteem by men." During his early years at the university, he lived what he characterized as a lighthearted lifestyle. Hus nowhere records a "conversion" experience as do Martin Luther and other religious reformers. Rather, he simply states that "when the Lord gave me knowledge of the Scriptures, I discarded from my foolish mind that kind of stupid fun making."Following his ordination in 1402, he was appointed rector and preacher of the Bethlehem Chapel in Prague. Founded in 1391, the Bethlehem Chapel was the point at which the Czech national movement coalesced with the cause of religious reform. Under the patronage of Charles IV, king of Bohemia, and his son Wenceslas IV, both of whom were also Holy Roman Emperors, Bethlehem Chapel was a refuge for a group of reform-minded Bohemian clergy, including John Milic of Kromerí and Matthew of Janov. They preached in the Czech language, rather than Latin, and hence were very popular with the common people.Jan Hus soon became the leader of the reform party centered in the Bethlehem Chapel and shared their condemnation of the corrupt clergy. Matthew of Janov characterized the priests as:worldly, proud, mercenary, pleasure-loving, and hypocritical. They do not regard their sins as such, do not allow themselves to be reproved, and persecute the saintly preachers. There is no doubt that if Jesus lived among such people, they would be the first to put him to death.Such outspoken opinions ran the risk of incurring the wrath of the church hierarchy. But so long as Hus and his associates enjoyed the protection of Wenceslas and Zybnek Zajic, the young reform-minded Archbishop of Prague, they were safe.What drew upon the reformers the charge of heresy was their acceptance of many of the theological teachings of John Wycliffe, a leading exponent of the philosophical position known as "realism." Prior to 1401, Hus knew only Wycliffe's philosophical works, but this was enough to incur the enmity of the German-dominated faculty of the university, for they were committed to the opposite philosophical position, "nominalism." The realists believed that universals have objective reality, whereas the nominalists held that universals or abstract concepts are mere names. For Wycliffe and his followers, this meant that in theology they emphasized the priority of faith over reason and the authority of the Scriptures (Bible) over church tradition.After the marriage of Wenceslas's half-sister Anne of Bohemia to Wycliffe's patron and defender, Richard II of England, a number of Bohemian students went to study under Wycliffe at Oxford University. As these students returned to the University of Prague, they brought with them the theological works of Wycliffe. Many of Wycliffe's views were congenial to the Bohemian reformers of the Bethlehem Chapel and accepted by them. Among them was Wycliffe's doctrine of the true Church. According to Wycliffe's understanding of Scripture, which he held to be authoritative, the true Church consisted of all thosepast, present, and futurepredestined by God to salvation. Since the Roman Catholic Church included both those predestined to salvation and those "foreknown" to damnation, it was not, as it believed itself to be, the true body of Christ. Hence, Wycliffe rejected the divine origin of the Roman Catholic Church and the alleged authority of the pope.Wycliffe also advocated "territorial churches, each protected, regulated, and supported by the territorial lords and princes." There was, of course, much more to Wycliffe's theological teaching, but the attraction it held for the Bohemians trying to liberate themselves from German cultural domination should be clear. Likewise, the connection with the 16th-century Reformation is clear. The fundamental doctrines of the Protestant Reformation are present in Wycliffe's teaching, and hence that of Hus, also.Jan Hus did not accept carte blanche all that Wycliffe taught. He did not, for example, accept Wycliffe's doctrine of remanence with respect to the Eucharist, or Mass. The doctrine of remanence held that in the celebration of the Eucharist, the bread and wine retain their material substance. Thus it denied the alleged miracle of transubstantiation by which, according to the Roman Catholic Church, the bread and wine became the flesh and blood of Christ. Transubstantiation was the key to the whole edifice of medieval theology. Remove it, and one removed the need for the priesthood and the medieval institutional church as it then existed.Although Hus did not agree with all that Wycliffe taught, and which his associates at Bethlehem Chapel and the university were teaching, he refused to denounce those views which he did not hold. The Bohemian party at the university was locked in a struggle with the German party for control of that institution. The Germans soon realized that their most effective way of countering the Bohemian party was to focus on its Wycliffism. Many of Wycliffe's teachings had been condemned by Pope Gregory XI and the English prelates, although Wycliffe died officially orthodox ("conforming to established doctrine").In 1403, Johann Hübner, one of the German masters at the university, drew up a list of 45 articles from Wycliffe's writings. Among them were the doctrine of remanence and the teaching that the Bible is the sole source of Christian doctrine. Hübner was able to have the 45 articles condemned as heresy. As they became a test of orthodoxy at the university, Hus was in danger of being branded a heretic and soon lost the support of both Archbishop Zbynek and King Wenceslas, although for different reasons. The change of events grew out of efforts to end the Great Schism.Wenceslas and the king of France (Charles VI) sought to end the Great Schism by convening a church council in Pisa in 1409. The Council deposed both Gregory XII (Rome) and Benedict XIII (Avignon), and elected Alexander VI, who was succeeded in 1410 by John XXIII. Since neither of the former two resigned, the number of popes was merely increased by one.The Council of Pisa and its aftermath sealed Hus's fate. Hus supported Wenceslas and recognized Alexander VI as pope. Zbynek and the German masters at the University of Prague refused to do so. When many of the German masters chose to leave Prague to found a new university at Leipzig in Germany, Zybnek began to take a closer look at Hus's teachings.In 1410, Archbishop Zybnek confiscated Wycliffe's books and ordered them burned. When Hus defended the books, Zybnek excommunicated him, and the following year Hus was ordered to appear in Rome. Refusing to go, Hus was excommunicated for disobedience. Having lost the support of his onetime ally, the Archbishop, Hus would next lose the support of his King.John XXIII proclaimed a crusade against King Ladislas of Naples, a supporter of John XXIII's rival, Gregory XII. The cost of the crusade was to be paid for by the sale of indulgences in, among other areas, Bohemia. Since Wenceslas was to receive a portion of the income from the sale of indulgences, he supported the crusade. Hus, however, openly condemned both and accused John XXIII of "trafficking in sacred things." Such action cost him and his associates the support of Wenceslas. Shortly thereafter, three members of the reform party who spoke out against indulgences were arrested and beheaded.In September 1412, a papal bull of excommunication of Hus was published in Prague. The city was placed under an interdict, and Bethlehem Chapel closed. An interdict was still a powerful weapon against heretics or other enemies of the church hierarchy. An area under interdict was denied the sacraments: "All masses and sermons, all religious functions, even burial with the Christian rites were prohibited." It was intended to turn the people of an area against the onein this case Huswho was defying the church authorities. To spare the city the rigors of being under an interdict, Hus withdrew from Prague and took refuge with various Bohemian nobles.The final act of Hus's life was played out at the Council of Constance (1414-18), called to bring an end to the Great Schism and to deal with the problem of heresy, especially Hus. Zygmunt, the king of Hungary and brother of Wenceslas, was elected Holy Roman Emperor in 1410. To strengthen his position in Germany, he pressured John XXIII to call the Council. Then, in the spring of 1415, offering a guarantee of safe conduct, Zygmunt invited Hus to attend. At first Hus hesitated, but with the urging of Wenceslas, he accepted.Once in Constance, Hus was lured into the papal residence, then imprisoned in a Dominican dungeon. What followed were months of interrogation and suffering. Zygmunt withdrew his safe conduct in January 1415. It was only due to great pressure exerted by Bohemian noblemen that Hus was given any semblance of a public hearing on June 5, 7, and 8, but he was not allowed to respond to the charges made against him. Presented with a list of 30 articles allegedly drawn from his writings but in fact drawn from the writings of John Wycliffe, Hus was ordered to renounce them upon oath. He refused, unless instructed from Scripture as to where his teachings were in error. The Council rejected his appeal to the Bible as a superior authority.On July 6, Hus was given a final opportunity to recant. Again he refused, saying that since he did not hold all of the views as stated, to recant would be to commit perjury. He was then declared an arch-heretic and a disciple of Wycliffe. He was ceremoniously degraded from the priest-hood, his soul was consigned to the devil, and he was turned over to the secular authorities for execution. That same day, he was led to a meadow outside the city wall and burned alive.Although the Council had consigned his soul to the devil, Hussinging loudly as the flames consumed him consigned his soul to God: "Jesus Christ! The Son of the living God! Have mercy upon me." His ashes were then gathered up and cast into the Rhine River.

[H1]Saddam Hussein[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Iraq[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1937 - 2006[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]A leading member of the revolutionary Ba'ath Party, which espoused secular pan-Arabism, economic modernization, and Arab socialism, Saddam Hussein played a key role in the 1968 coup that brought the party to long-term power. As vice president under the ailing General Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr, Saddam tightly controlled conflict between the government and the armed forces - at a time when many other groups were considered capable of overthrowing the government - by creating repressive security forces. In the early 1970s, Saddam spearheaded Iraq's nationalization of the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company, which had long held a monopoly on the country's oil. Through the 1970s, Saddam cemented his authority over the apparatuses of government as Iraq's economy grew at a rapid pace.[PARAGRAPH:1]As president, Saddam maintained power during the Iran-Iraq War (1980-1988) and the first Persian Gulf War (1991). During these conflicts, Saddam repressed movements he considered threatening to the stability of Iraq, particularly Shi'a and Kurdish movements seeking to overthrow the government or gain independence, respectively. Whereas some Arabs looked upon him as a hero for his aggressive stance against foreign intervention and for his support for the Palestinians, United States leaders continued to view Saddam with deep suspicion following the 1991 Persian Gulf War. Saddam was deposed by the U.S. and its allies during the 2003 invasion of Iraq.[PARAGRAPH:1]Saddam saw himself as a social revolutionary and a modernizer, following the Nasser model. To the consternation of Islamic conservatives, his government gave women added freedoms and offered them high-level government and industry jobs. Saddam also created a Western-style legal system, making Iraq the only country in the Persian Gulf region not ruled according to traditional Islamic law (Sharia). Saddam abolished the Sharia law courts, except for personal injury claims.[PARAGRAPH:1]As a sign of his consolidation of power, Saddam's personality cult pervaded Iraqi society. Thousands of portraits, posters, statues and murals were erected in his honor all over Iraq. His face could be seen on the sides of office buildings, schools, airports, and shops, as well as on Iraqi currency. Saddam's personality cult reflected his efforts to appeal to the various elements in Iraqi society. He appeared in the costumes of the Bedouin, the traditional clothes of the Iraqi peasant (which he essentially wore during his childhood), and even Kurdish clothing, but also appeared in Western suits, projecting the image of an urbane and modern leader. Sometimes he would also be portrayed as a devout Muslim, wearing full headdress and robe, praying toward Mecca.[PARAGRAPH:1]Captured by U.S. forces on December 13, 2003, Saddam was brought to trial under the Iraqi interim government set up by U.S.-led forces. On November 5, 2006, he was convicted of charges related to the executions of 148 Iraqi Shi'ites suspected of planning an assassination attempt against him, and was sentenced to death by hanging. Saddam was executed on December 30, 2006.

[H1]Idris II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of Morocco[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] c.791 - 828 AD[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Idris II was the son of Idris I, the founder of the Idrisid dynasty in North Africa. He was born in Volubilis (Morocco) two months after the death of his father. Idris II was the great great grandchild of Hassan, son of Ali the cousin of the prophet Muhammad.[PARAGRAPH:1]The death of Idris I, and the resulting destabilisation of the fledgling Idrisid dynasty state, delighted the Caliph in Baghdad. However, two months later, a concubine of Idris I gave birth to Idris II, who became a quick prodigy.[PARAGRAPH:1]In reference to Idris II, the historian Rom Landau, says: "In the lore of the Moroccans, Idris II was a being of almost magical attributes. An exceptional young man he certainly must have been. At many points we are reminded of one of the greatest sages of Islam, Ibn Sina or Avicenna. At the age of four little Idris apparently could read, at five write, at eight he knew the Koran by heart, and by then is said to have mastered the wisdom of all the outstanding savants. He was of real physical strength as well, and when he became officially sovereign in 805 at the age of thirteen, he had already accomplished feats of endurance that men twice his age could not emulate. His profound Islamic faith enhanced all these advantages and increased the veneration accorded him."[PARAGRAPH:1]Twenty years after his father had done so, Idris II refounded the city Fez on the left bank of the river Fez, opposite to where his father had founded it on the right bank. From there on, Idris II began to unify Maghreb under Islam, establishing its firm allegiance to the belief. After spending 19 years pursuing such purposes, this prodigy died at 35 in 828. For twelve hundred years afterwards, the tradition of monarchy, established by Idris I and II, were continued.[PARAGRAPH:1]

[H1]Ithobaal I[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Tyre[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 915 - 847 BC[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ithobaal I (or Ethbaal; Biblical Ethbaal, 1 Kings 16:31) was a king of Tyre who founded a new dynasty. During his reign, Tyre expanded its power on the mainland, making all of Phoenicia its territory as far north as Beirut, including Sidon, and even a part of the island of Cyprus. At the same time, Tyre also built new overseas colonies: Botrys (now Batrun) near Byblos, and Auza in Libya.Primary information related to Ithobaal comes from Josephuss citation of the Phoenician author Menander of Ephesus, in Against Apion i.18. Here it is said that the previous king, Phelles, was slain by Ithobalus, the priest of Astarte, who reigned thirty-two years, and lived sixty-eight years; he was succeeded by his son Badezorus (Baal-Eser II). The dates given here are according to the work of F. M. Cross and other scholars who take 825 BC as the date of Didos flight from her brother Pygmalion, after which she founded the city of Carthage in 814 BC. See the chronological justification for these dates in the Pygmalion article.Ithobaal held close diplomatic contacts with king Ahab of Israel. First Kings 16:31 relates that his daughter Jezebel married Ahab (874  853 BC), and Phoenician influence in Samaria and the other Israelite cities was extensive. In the 1 Kings passage, Ithobaal is labeled king of the Sidonians. At this time Tyre and Sidon were consolidated into one kingdom. Menanders comment that Ithobaal had been a priest of Astarte before becoming king explains why his daughter Jezebel was so zealous in the promotion of idolatry, thus leading to the conflicts between Elijah and Jezebels forces described in 1 Kings 18 and 19. Menanders further statement that her father was a murderer sheds some light on her choice of a way to solve the Naboth problem in 1 Kings 21. Tyre is not mentioned as an opponent of Shalmaneser III at the Battle of Qarqar in 853 BC, but twelve years later, in 841, Ithobaals son Baal-Eser II gave tribute to the Assyrian monarch.

TEXT.English: [H1]Janybek Khan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Co-leader of the Kazakh Khanate[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruled: [\BOLD] c. 1465 - 1480 [NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Janybek (or Janibek, Zhanibek, Jani Beg) Khan was a co-leader of a new Kazakh Khanate, following a successful rebellion against the Uzbek Khan Abu'l-Khayr Khan in 1465 and 1466. Janybek's father was Baraq (Khan of Golden Horde) who was poisoned by emirs of the former White Horde. He led the splinter group along with Kerei (or Girei or Keray), who was his relative, and who was also descended from the famous Urus Khan of the White Horde. For his wisdom, he was given the title "Az", meaning "the wise" in the Kazakh language, and so was called Az-Zhanibek. His son, Kasym Khan codified the laws of his people.

[H1]Jezebel[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Princess of Phoenicia, Queen of Israel[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]c.9th Century BC[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Jezebel was a Phoenician princess, identified in the Hebrew Book of Kings as the daughter of Ethbaal, King of the Sidonians (Phoenicians) and the wife of Ahab, king of north Israel. According to genealogies given in Josephus and other classical sources she was the great aunt of Dido, Queen of Carthage.The Hebrew text portrays Jezebel as an evil power behind the throne. Ahab and Jezebel allow temples of Baal to operate in Israel, and that religion receives royal patronage. After Ahab's death, his sons by Jezebel, Ahaziah and Jehoram, accede to the throne. The prophet Elisha has one of his servants anoint Jehu as king to overthrow the house of Ahab. Jehu kills Jehoram as he attempts to flee in his war chariot. He then confronts Jezebel in Jezreel and urges her eunuchs to kill the queen mother by throwing her out of a window and leaving her corpse in the street to be eaten by dogs. Only Jezebel's skull, feet, and hands remain. Jezebel's final act, equipping herself in all her finery before she is murdered, has led to her being represented as a kind of prostitute.Jezebel's story is told in 1st and 2nd Kings. The story concerns an intense religious-political struggle  the most detailed such account of any period in the history of the Kingdom of Israel  written from a highly partisan point of view, with no surviving documents to represent the other side of the controversy. The account is mainly interested in the religious side of the events, with the political, economic and social background  highly important to modern historiansgiven only incidentally. She is introduced as a Phoenician princess, the daughter of Ethbaal, king of the Phoenician empire and marries King Ahab of the Northern Kingdom (i.e. Israel during the time when ancient Israel was divided into Israel in the north and Judah in the south). She helps convert Ahab from worship of the Jewish God to worship of the Phoenician god Baal. After she has many Jewish prophets killed, Elijah challenges 450 prophets of Baal to a competition (1 Kings 18), exposes the rival god as powerless and goes on to have prophets of Baal slaughtered (1 Kings 18:40), thereby incurring Jezebel's furious enmity. To Barzowski, Ahab's marriage to Jezebel was  at least to begin with  obviously a dynastic marriage intended to cement a Phoenician alliance, going back to the times of King Solomon, that gave the inland Kingdom of Israel access to international trade. The monarchy (and possibly an urban elite connected with it) enjoyed the wealth derived from this trade, which gave it a stronger position vis-a-vis the rural landowners and made for a more centralized and powerful monarchical administration. The story of Naboth, a landowner who was killed at the instigation of Jezebel so that the King could acquire his land, certainly points in this direction  Jezebel, with her foreign religion and cosmopolitan culture, representing a hated Phoenician alliance from which the landowners had little to gain and much to lose. Their resentment was expressed in religious terms (as in many other times and places), and eventually got a political expression in Jehu's bloody coup, instigated and supported by the prophets whose side of the story the Bible preserves.

[H1]Mohammad Ali Jinnah[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Governor-General of Pakistan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]1876 - 1948[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]The eldest son of a hide merchant, Jinnah was educated at the Sind Madrassa and Lincoln's Inn, London, where he qualified as a barrister. The future founder of Pakistan was first known as the ambassador of Hindu-Muslim unity. Indeed Jinnah only resigned from Congress in 1920 when he became disillusioned with the violence and communal passions unleashed by Gandhi's Congress-Khilafat civil disobedience campaigns. The division widened in 1928 when the Nehru Report rejected Jinnah's "fourteen points" constitutional proposals. During 1921  35, Jinnah's political career was in the doldrums. He returned to India in October 1935 after a five-year British exile to reorganize the Muslim League. It nevertheless lost heavily in the 1937 provincial elections. The Congress ministries' insensitivity to Muslim demands rescued it from oblivion, although Jinnah's leadership was equally crucial to its dramatic transformation. From 1940 onwards, he propounded the two-nation theory justification for Pakistan and increasingly embodied the aspirations of the Indian Muslim community which acclaimed him as the Quaid-i-Azam, the great leader. Within the fractious politics of the Muslim League, he exerted an unquestioned moral authority which underpinned his formal power as President. Simultaneously he deployed his forensic skills in the complex constitutional negotiations with the British and the Congress. Jinnah's successful claim to be the sole spokesman of Muslim India at the July 1945 Simla conference greatly strengthened the Pakistan demand. During 1946  7, however, he suffered a series of reversals as the Muslim League lost its wartime bargaining power. He had to abandon his strictly constitutional approach to politics, but the resulting communal riots threatened civil war. Agreement for Partition was finally reached on 3 June 1947: the Pakistan which emerged was not of the full six Muslim provinces of Jinnah's dreams, but a moth-eaten country shorn of West Bengal and East Punjab. Mass migrations and massacres accompanied the Punjab's partition. The refugee crisis increased Pakistan's formidable security and administrative problems. Jinnah, who was both Pakistan's Governor-General and Constituent Assembly President, assumed much of the burden for laying the state's foundations. He was by now 70 and appeared frailer and more emaciated than ever. It remains doubtful however whether if he had lived longer than September 1948, Pakistan could have avoided its growing crisis of governability. Jinnah is still revered as Pakistan's founding father. Islamists improbably and secularists more soundly have attempted to claim his mantle. Recent revisionist scholarship, however, has speculated that Partition was the unintended consequence of his trumpeting the Pakistan demand as a bargaining counter for power in a united India.

[H1]Jogaila[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Grand Duke of Lithuania, King of Poland[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1362 - 1434 AD[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Jogaila was born to Algirdas, Grand Duke of Lithuania, and his second wife, Uliana, daughter of Alexander I, Grand Prince of Tver. When Jogaila succeeded to the throne in 1377, Lithuania contained two different nationalities and two political systems: ethnic Lithuania in the northwest and the vast Ruthenian territories of the former Kievan Rus', comprising lands of modern Ukraine, Belarus, and parts of western Russia. At first, Jogaila based his rule in southern and eastern territories in Lithuania, while his uncle continued to rule the northwestern region. [PARAGRAPH: 1] At the beginning of his reign, Jogaila confronted unrest in the Lithuanian Rus' lands. In the northwest, Lithuania faced constant thread from the monastic state of the Teutonic Order, which was founded in 1226 to fight and convert the pagan Baltic tries of Prussians, Yotvingians, and Lithuanians. In return for the Order's backing against Jogaila's uncle, Jogaila agreed to the Christianization of Lithuania. However, Jogaila's uncle discovered the plan, seized Vilnius, overthrew Jogaila, and pronounced himself Grand Duke in his place. Jogaila's uncle, with the help of his son Vytautas, entered Jogaila's encampment in Vilnius. The uncle was later murdered, and Vytautas escaped. Jogaila conducted further talks with the Teutonic Order, but later was betrayed by them. Jogaila then allied himself with Vytautas to, in retaliation, loot and attack several Prussian castles. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Jogaila's choice to marry a Christian wife was evident, and he therefore married the young Queen Jadwiga of Poland. Jogaila also signed a treaty with Poland agreeing to his Christianization and the returning of the lands taken from Poland by its neighbors. Another agreement concerning a union between Lithuania and Poland was also signed when the marriage took place. When Jogaila was baptized in 1386, Lithuania's Christianization began. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Jogaila and Jadwiga reigned as co-monarchs, and Jadwiga made several contributions to Poland's political and cultural life. Jogaila then passed several laws unifying the two legal systems of Poland and Lithuania that achieved a lasting influence on history. During the following years, he faced continuous challenges. The Teutonic Knights failed to end their crusades claiming Jogaila's conversion to Christianity was false. Jogaila and Jadwiga sponsored the creation of the Diocese of Vilnius and other religious reforms. Jogaila faced a revived challenge from Vytautas, who resented the power given to Skirgaila in Lithuania at the expense of his own patrimony. In 1390, Vytautas and the Teutonic Knights laid siege to Vilnius and destroyed the outer city. In order to gain peace with Vytautas, Jogaila handed over the throne of Lithuania to him. However, Vytautas continued to demand Lithuania's separation from Poland. Later, after being crushed by the Timurids in a battle, Vytautas was forced to give in to Jogaila's protection once again. [PARAGRAPH: 1] In 1399, Jadwiga died while giving birth, leaving Jogaila the sole ruler of Poland without an heir. In 1401, Vytautas was recognized as Grand Duke under Jogaila's overlordship, also allowing Jogaila's heirs, rather than those of Vytautas, to succeed to the throne. If no heirs were born, the Lithuanian boyars would elect a new monarch. This act forged an alliance between Poland and Lithuania, strengthening both for another war against the Teutonic Order. However, after problems within borders, Jogaila was defeated after a war with the Teutonic Order, and gave in to their demands. In 1408, Jogaila and Vytautas held strategic talks in Navahrudak, where they decided to revolt against Teutonic rule in portions of Lithuania. The Order declared war against Poland that same year. [PARAGRAPH: 1] The castles on the northern border were easily captured by the Teutonic Knights, and both sides prepared for a major confrontation that winter. Both sides received support from various European countries. However, after one of the largest and most ferocious battles of the Middle Ages, Jogaila and his army were victors. Jogaila, however, hesitated to move on to the capital of Marienburg, and thus suffered a loss at the city. The war ended in 1411 in which neither Poland nor Lithuania returned home with all of what they hoped to earn. Lithuania regained much of its territory after the war, but the Polish people began to revive their distrust of Jogaila. Jogaila made several attempts to strengthen his relations with the Polish people, including permanently forming a union between Poland and Lithuania. [PARAGRAPH: 1] A new war broke out between the Knights and Poland, but ended in nothing, as both sides were still worn out from the last war. Jogaila continued to be questioned and scandalized by his people, and lost the popularity he once had. In 1422, Jogaila fought another war against the Teutonic Order, defeating them in under two months. Further sporadic wars broke out between Poland and the Knights between 1431 and 1435. Jogaila died in 1434, leaving Poland to his elder son and Lithuania to his younger, both were minors at the time.
TEXT.French: [H1]Jogaila[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Grand-Duc de Lituanie, Roi de Pologne[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates :[\BOLD] 1362 - 1434 ap. J.C.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Jogaila est né à Algirdas, Grand-Duc de Lituanie, et de sa seconde épouse, Uliana, fille d'Alexandre Ier, le Grand Prince de Tver. Quand Jogaila a succédé sur le trône en 1377, la Lituanie contenait deux nationalités différentes et de deux systèmes politiques: Lituanie ethniques dans le nord-ouest et la grande ruthène territoires de l'ancienne Kievan Rus', qui comprend les terres moderne de l'Ukraine, la Biélorussie, et des parties de l'ouest de la Russie. Au début, les Jagellon fondé son règne dans le sud et l'est du territoire en Lituanie, tandis que son oncle continué de gouverner la région nord-ouest. [PARAGRAPH 1] Au début de son règne, Jagellon confrontés troubles dans le lituanien Rus' terres. Dans le nord-ouest, la Lituanie font face à de constantes fil de l'état monastique de l'Ordre teutonique, qui a été fondée en 1226 à se battre et à convertir les païens Baltique essaie de Prussiens, Yotvingians, et les Lituaniens. En retour de l'Ordre soutien contre l'oncle de Jagellon, Ladislas II Jagellon convenu de la christianisation de la Lituanie. Toutefois, l'oncle de Jagellon découvert ce plan, à la saisie de Vilnius, a renversé Jagellon, et se prononce Grand-Duc à sa place. Jogaila son oncle, avec l'aide de son fils, Vytautas, est entré Jagellon de cantonnement à Vilnius. L'oncle a été assassiné plus tard, et Vytautas échappé. Jogaila mené de nouvelles discussions avec l'Ordre teutonique, mais plus tard a été trahi par eux. Jagellon puis s'allie avec Vytautas, en représailles, de piller et d'attaquer plusieurs châteaux de Prusse. [PARAGRAPH 1] Jagellon son choix d'épouser une chrétienne épouse était évident, et il a donc épousé la jeune reine Jadwiga de Pologne. Jogaila a également signé un traité avec la Pologne acceptant sa christianisation et de la restitution de terres de la prise de la Pologne par ses voisins. Un autre accord concernant l'union entre la Lituanie et la Pologne a également été signé lorsque le mariage a eu lieu. Quand Jagellon fut baptisé en 1386, la Lituanie a commencé christianisation. [PARAGRAPH 1] Jagellon et Jadwiga régna en tant que co-monarques, et Jadwiga fait plusieurs contributions à la Pologne de la vie politique et culturelle. Jogaila ensuite adopté plusieurs lois sur l'unification des deux systèmes juridiques, de la Pologne et la Lituanie, qui a obtenu une influence durable sur l'histoire. Au cours des années suivantes, il continue défis rencontrés. Les chevaliers teutoniques pas réussi à mettre fin à leurs croisades Jagellon revendiquant la conversion au christianisme était fausse. Jagellon et Jadwiga parrainé la création du diocèse de Vilnius et d'autres réformes religieuses. Jogaila relancé face à un défi de Vytautas, qui a ressenti le pouvoir donné à Skirgaila en Lituanie, au détriment de son propre patrimoine. En 1390, Vytautas et de l'Ordre teutonique assiégé à Vilnius et détruit l'extérieur ville. Afin de gagner la paix avec Vytautas, Ladislas II Jagellon remis le trône de la Lituanie auprès de lui. Toutefois, Vytautas Lituanie a continué d'exiger la séparation de la Pologne. Plus tard, après avoir été écrasé par le Timurids dans une bataille, Vytautas a été forcé de céder à la protection Jagellon une fois de plus. [PARAGRAPH 1] En 1399, Jadwiga est mort tout en donnant naissance, laissant Jagellon le seul dirigeant de la Pologne, sans un héritier. En 1401, a été reconnue comme Vytautas le Grand-Duc Jogaila sous l'overlordship, en autorisant également les héritiers de Ladislas II Jagellon, plutôt que celles de Vytautas, pour succéder au trône. Si les héritiers ne sont nés, les boyards lituanien serait élire un nouveau monarque. Cet acte forgé une alliance entre la Pologne et la Lituanie, renforçant à la fois pour une nouvelle guerre contre l'Ordre teutonique. Cependant, après des problèmes au sein de frontières, les Jagellon a été vaincu après une guerre avec l'Ordre teutonique, et cédé à leurs exigences. En 1408, Ladislas II Jagellon et Vytautas tenue stratégique pourparlers à Navahrudak, où ils ont décidé de se révolter contre Teutonique règle dans certaines parties de la Lituanie. L'Ordre a déclaré la guerre contre la Pologne, la même année. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Les châteaux sur la frontière nord sont facilement capturés par les chevaliers teutoniques, et les deux parties ont préparé pour une confrontation majeure que l'hiver. Les deux parties ont reçu le soutien de plusieurs pays européens. Toutefois, après l'un des plus grands et des plus féroces batailles du Moyen Age, Jagellon et son armée ont été vainqueurs. Ladislas II Jagellon, cependant, hésité à passer à la capitale de Marienburg, et donc subi une perte lors de la ville. La guerre a pris fin en 1411 dans lequel ni la Pologne, ni la Lituanie rentre à la maison avec tous ce qu'ils espéraient gagner. Lituanie a retrouvé une grande partie de son territoire après la guerre, mais le peuple polonais a commencé à raviver leur méfiance à l'égard des Jagellon. Jogaila tente à plusieurs reprises de renforcer ses relations avec le peuple polonais, y compris la formation d'une union permanente entre la Pologne et la Lituanie. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Une nouvelle guerre a éclaté entre les Chevaliers et de la Pologne, mais a pris fin en rien, car les deux parties étaient encore usé de la dernière guerre. Jogaila a continué d'être question et scandalisé par son peuple, et a perdu la popularité, il a une fois. En 1422, Ladislas II Jagellon combattu une autre guerre contre l'Ordre teutonique, les vaincre en moins de deux mois. D'autres guerres sporadiques ont éclaté entre la Pologne et les Chevaliers entre 1431 et 1435. Jagellon mourut en 1434, laissant la Pologne à son fils aîné et de la Lituanie à son jeune, les deux étaient mineurs à l'époque.
TEXT.German: [H1]Jogaila[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Großherzog von Litauen, König von Polen[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1362 - 1434 n. Chr. [NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Wladyslaw II. Jagiello, geboren zu Algirdas, Großherzog von Litauen, und seiner zweiten Frau, Uliana, Tochter von Alexander I., Großfürst von Twer. Als Wladyslaw II. Auf den ersten, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello stützte seine Herrschaft in den südlichen und östlichen Gebiete in Litauen, während sein Onkel weiter Regel der nordwestlichen Region. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Zu Beginn seiner Regierungszeit, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello konfrontiert Unruhen in der litauischen Rus' landet. Im Nordwesten, Litauen, denen konstant Thread aus der klösterlichen Staat des Deutschen Ordens, der 1226 gegründet wurde und zu bekämpfen und zu konvertieren, die heidnischen baltischen versucht von Preußen, Yotvingians und Litauer. Im Gegenzug für die Unterstützung des Ordens gegen Onkel Wladyslaw II. Jagiello, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello vereinbart, die Christianisierung von Litauen. Allerdings, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello Onkel entdeckte den Plan, beschlagnahmt Vilnius, stürzten Wladyslaw II. Jagiello, und sprach sich Großherzog an seinem Platz ist. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello Onkel, der mit Hilfe von seinem Sohn Vytautas, trat Wladyslaw II. Jagiello's Camp in Vilnius. Der Onkel wurde später ermordet, und Vytautas entkam. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello, dann verbündete sich mit Vytautas, in der Vergeltung, Beute angegriffen und mehrere preußischen Schlössern. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Wladyslaw II. Jagiello Wahl zu heiraten, eine christliche Frau war offensichtlich, und er daher heiratete die junge Königin Jadwiga von Polen. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello auch einen Vertrag mit Polen die Zustimmung zu seiner Rückkehr und der Christianisierung des Landes, die aus Polen von seinem Nachbarn. Ein weiteres Abkommen über eine Union zwischen Litauen und Polen wurde auch, wenn die Ehe stattfand. Als Wladyslaw II. Jagiello wurde in 1386 getauft, Litauen's Christianisierung begann. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Wladyslaw II. Jagiello Jadwiga und regierte als Co-Monarchen, und Jadwiga aus mehreren Beiträgen zu Polen die politischen und kulturellen Leben. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello dann mehrere Gesetze Vereinheitlichung der beiden Rechtssysteme von Polen und Litauen, einen dauerhaften Einfluss auf die Geschichte. In den folgenden Jahren hat er sich kontinuierlich Herausforderungen. Die Kreuzritter nicht beenden ihre Kreuzzüge behaupten Wladyslaw II. Jagiello die Konvertierung zum Christentum war falsch. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello Jadwiga gesponsert und die Schaffung der Diözese von Vilnius und anderen religiösen Reformen. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello wieder vor einer Herausforderung von Vytautas, übelgenommen, die die Macht an Skirgaila in Litauen auf Kosten seiner eigenen Erbes. In 1390, Vytautas und den Deutschen Ritterorden, die Belagerung zu Wilna und zerstörte den äußeren Stadt. Um zu gewinnen, den Frieden mit Vytautas, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello übergab den Thron von Litauen zu ihm. Allerdings, Vytautas weiterhin Nachfrage Litauen's Trennung von Polen. Später, nachdem er erdrückt von der Timurids in einer Schlacht, Vytautas war gezwungen zu geben und zu Wladyslaw II. Jagiello-Schutz wieder. [PARAGRAPH: 1] In 1399, Jadwiga starb während der Geburt, so dass der alleinige Herrscher Wladyslaw II. Jagiello von Polen ohne Erben. In 1401, Vytautas war als Grand Duke's overlordship unter Wladyslaw II. Jagiello, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello auch die Erben, sondern als die von Vytautas, zur Thronfolge. Wenn keine Erben geboren wurden, die litauischen Bojaren würde wählt einen neuen Monarchen. Dieser Akt schmiedete eine Allianz zwischen Polen und Litauen, die Stärkung sowohl für einen neuen Krieg gegen den Deutschen Orden. Allerdings, nach Problemen innerhalb der Grenzen, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello wurde nach einem Krieg mit dem Deutschen Orden, und gab sich in ihren Forderungen. In 1408, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello und Vytautas hielt strategische Gespräche in Navahrudak, wo sie beschlossen, die Revolte gegen die germanische Regel in Portionen von Litauen. Der Orden den Krieg gegen Polen im selben Jahr. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Die Schlösser an der nördlichen Grenze gefangen genommen wurden leicht durch den Deutschen Ritterorden, und beide Seiten bereit für eine große Konfrontation, die im Winter. Beide Seiten erhielten Unterstützung aus verschiedenen europäischen Ländern. Allerdings, nach einer der größten und wildesten Schlachten des Mittelalters, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello und seine Armee wurden Sieger. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello, aber zögerte, um auf die Hauptstadt der Marienburg, und somit einen Verlust erlitten in der Stadt. Der Krieg endete 1411, in dem weder Polen noch Litauen kehrten nach Hause zurück mit allem, was sie hoffen, zu verdienen. Litauen wieder viel von seinem Hoheitsgebiet nach dem Krieg, sondern das polnische Volk begann zu beleben, sein Misstrauen von Wladyslaw II. Jagiello. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello aus mehreren Versuchen zu stärken, seine Beziehungen mit der polnischen Volkes, einschließlich der Bildung einer Gewerkschaft permanent zwischen Polen und Litauen. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Ein neuer Krieg zwischen den Knights und Polen, aber in nichts beendet, da beide Seiten noch getragen aus dem letzten Krieg. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello fortgesetzt werden und die Frage angeeckt von seinem Volk, und die Popularität verloren, die er einst hatte. In 1422, Wladyslaw II. Jagiello kämpfte einen neuen Krieg gegen den Deutschen Orden, sie zu besiegen, in weniger als zwei Monaten. Weitere sporadisch brachen Kriege zwischen Polen und der Ritter zwischen 1431 und 1435. Wladyslaw II. Jagiello starb 1434, so dass Polen zu seinem älteren Sohn und Litauen bis zu seinem jüngeren, beide wurden von Minderjährigen zu dieser Zeit.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Jogaila[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Granduca di Lituania, Re di Polonia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vita:[\BOLD] 1362 - 1434 d.C. [NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Informazioni:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Jogaila è nato a Algirdas, Granduca di Lituania, e la sua seconda moglie, Uliana, figlia di Alessandro I, Gran Principe di Tver. Quando Jogaila succeduto al trono nel 1377, la Lituania conteneva due nazionalità diverse e due sistemi politici: etnica Lituania nel nord-ovest, e la stragrande ruteni territori della ex Kiev Rus', che comprende le terre della moderna Ucraina, la Bielorussia, e parti della Russia occidentale. In un primo tempo, Jogaila basa la sua regola e meridionale e orientale territori in Lituania, mentre suo zio continuò a governare la regione nord-occidentale. [PARAGRAPH: 1] All'inizio del suo regno, di fronte Jogaila disordini in lituano Rus' terre. Nel nord-ovest, la Lituania fronte costante filo da monastica stato della Teutonico, che è stata fondata nel 1226 per combattere e convertire i pagani baltici cerca di prussiani, Yotvingians, e lituani. In cambio, per l'Ordine di appoggio contro Jogaila's zio, Jogaila accettato la cristianizzazione della Lituania. Tuttavia, Jogaila's zio scoperto il piano, sequestrati Vilnius, Jogaila rovesciato, e una marcata se stesso Granduca al suo posto. Jogaila's zio, con l'aiuto di suo figlio Vytautas, entrato Jogaila's accampamento a Vilnius. Lo zio fu poi assassinato, e Vytautas escape. Jogaila condotti ulteriori colloqui con l'Ordine Teutonico, ma in seguito è stato tradito da loro. Jogaila poi si alleò con Vytautas, per ritorsione, bottino attacco più prussiana e castelli. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Jogaila, la scelta di sposare un cristiano moglie era evidente, e pertanto egli sposò la giovane regina Edvige di Polonia. Jogaila inoltre firmato un trattato con la Polonia, accettando la sua cristianizzazione e il ritorno delle terre prese dalla Polonia con i suoi vicini. Un'altra, relativa ad un accordo di unione tra la Lituania e la Polonia, è stato firmato anche quando il matrimonio ha avuto luogo. Quando Jogaila fu battezzato nel 1386, la Lituania ha iniziato la cristianizzazione. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Jogaila e Jadwiga regnato come co-monarchi, e Jadwiga fatto diversi contributi alla Polonia la vita politica e culturale. Jogaila poi passò varie leggi unificante i due sistemi giuridici di Polonia e Lituania, che ha raggiunto una duratura influenza sulla storia. Negli anni seguenti, ha di fronte sfide continue. Il Cavaliere Teutonico non ha fine il loro crociate Jogaila rivendicando la conversione al cristianesimo era falso. Jogaila e Jadwiga sponsorizzato la creazione della diocesi di Vilnius e di altre riforme religiose. Jogaila dovuto affrontare una sfida rianimato da Vytautas, che risentì il potere dato a Skirgaila in Lituania, a scapito del proprio patrimonio. Nel 1390, Vytautas Teutonico Cavalieri e il cui assedio a Vilnius e distrutto l'esterno della città. Al fine di ottenere la pace con Vytautas, Jogaila consegnato il trono di Lituania a lui. Tuttavia, Vytautas Lituania ha continuato a chiedere la separazione dalla Polonia. Più tardi, dopo essere stato schiacciato dal Timurids in una battaglia, Vytautas è stato costretto a cedere al Jogaila's protezione ancora una volta. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Nel 1399, Jadwiga morì mentre la nascita di un figlio, lasciando Jogaila l'unico governante della Polonia senza un erede. Nel 1401, è stato riconosciuto come Vytautas Granduca Jogaila sotto's overlordship, consentendo anche Jogaila's eredi, piuttosto che quelli di Vytautas, per avere successo al trono. Se non sono nati eredi, il lituano boyars sarebbe eleggere un nuovo monarca. Questo atto forgiato un'alleanza tra la Polonia e la Lituania, il rafforzamento sia per una nuova guerra contro l'Ordine Teutonico. Tuttavia, dopo i problemi all'interno di frontiere, Jogaila è stato sconfitto dopo una guerra con l'Ordine Teutonico, e ha dato e alle loro richieste. Nel 1408, Jogaila e Vytautas terrà colloqui strategici e Navahrudak, dove hanno deciso di rivolta contro Teutonico regola in porzioni di Lituania. L'Ordine ha dichiarato guerra contro la Polonia in quello stesso anno. [PARAGRAPH: 1] I castelli sul confine settentrionale erano facilmente catturato dai Teutonico Cavalieri, e di entrambi i lati preparato per un importante confronto che invernale. Entrambe le parti hanno ricevuto sostegno da vari paesi europei. Tuttavia, dopo una delle più grandi e più feroci battaglie del Medio Evo, Jogaila e il suo esercito sono stati vincitori. Jogaila, tuttavia, esitato a muoversi verso la capitale di Marienburg, e, quindi, subito una perdita in città. La guerra terminò nel 1411, in cui né la Polonia né Lituania tornato a casa con tutto quello che sperava di guadagnare. Lituania riacquistato gran parte del suo territorio, dopo la guerra, ma il popolo polacco ha iniziato a ravvivare la loro diffidenza di Jogaila. Jogaila fatto diversi tentativi di rafforzare le sue relazioni con il popolo polacco, compresi permanentemente formazione di una unione tra la Polonia e la Lituania. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Una nuova guerra scoppiata tra il Cavaliere e la Polonia, ma alla fine nel nulla, in quanto entrambe le parti erano ancora esaurita da l'ultima guerra. Jogaila continuato ad essere scandalizzati dalla questione e il suo popolo, e perde la popolarità che si era una volta. Nel 1422, un altro Jogaila lottato contro la guerra Teutonico, sconfitto in meno di due mesi. Ulteriori sporadici guerre scoppiata tra la Polonia e Cavalieri tra 1431 e 1435. Jogaila morì nel 1434, lasciando la Polonia per il suo figlio maggiore e la Lituania ai suoi giovani, entrambi erano minorenni al momento.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Jogaila[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gran Duque de Lituania, Rey de Polonia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 1362 - 1434 d. C. [NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Historia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Jogaila nació a Algirdas, Gran Duque de Lituania, y de su segunda esposa, Uliana, hija de Alejandro I, el Gran Príncipe de Tver. Cuando Jogaila sucesión al trono en 1377, Lituania contiene dos nacionalidades diferentes y dos sistemas políticos: Lituania étnica en el noroeste y la gran rutenio territorios de la antigua Rus de Kiev ", que comprende tierras de la moderna Ucrania, Bielorrusia, y partes del oeste de Rusia. Al principio, Jogaila basa su imperio en el sur y el este de los territorios en Lituania, mientras que su tío siguen gobernando la región noroeste. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Al principio de su reinado, Jogaila enfrentan disturbios en el lituano Rus' tierras. En el noroeste, Lituania se enfrentan constante hilo de la monástica estado de la Orden Teutónica, que se fundó en 1226 para luchar contra la conversión de los paganos y el Báltico trata de prusianos, Yotvingians, y los lituanos. A cambio de la Orden del respaldo contra el tío de Jogaila, Jogaila de acuerdo a la cristianización de Lituania. Sin embargo, el tío de Jogaila descubrió el plan, se apoderó de Vilnius, derrocó Jogaila, y él mismo pronuncia Gran Duque en su lugar. Jogaila del tío, con la ayuda de su hijo Vytautas, entró Jogaila del campamento en Vilnius. El tío fue asesinado más tarde, y Vytautas escapó. Jogaila llevó a cabo nuevas conversaciones con la Orden Teutónica, pero más tarde fue traicionado por ellos. Jogaila entonces aliado a sí mismo con Vytautas, en represalia, el ataque y saqueo de varios castillos prusiana. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Jogaila escogió para casarse con una mujer cristiana era evidente, y por lo tanto, se casó con el joven reina Jadwiga de Polonia. Jogaila también firmó un tratado con Polonia de acuerdo a su cristianización y la devolución de las tierras tomadas de Polonia por sus vecinos. Otro acuerdo relativo a una unión entre Lituania y Polonia también fue firmado cuando el matrimonio se haya celebrado. Jogaila cuando fue bautizado en 1386, se inició la cristianización de Lituania. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Jogaila y Jadwiga reinó como co-monarcas, y Jadwiga hizo varias contribuciones a Polonia en la vida política y cultural. Jogaila entonces pasó varias leyes unificación de los dos sistemas jurídicos de Polonia y Lituania, que logró una duradera influencia en la historia. Durante los siguientes años, se enfrentaba a retos continuos. Los Caballeros no Teutónica a poner fin a sus cruzadas alegando Jogaila la conversión al cristianismo era falsa. Jogaila Jadwiga y patrocinó la creación de la Diócesis de Vilnius y otras reformas religiosas. Jogaila enfrenta desafío de reactivar un Vytautas, resentimiento, que el poder dado a Skirgaila en Lituania a costa de su propio patrimonio. En 1390, Vytautas y la Teutónica Caballeros sitiaron a Vilnius y destruyó la ciudad exterior. A fin de obtener la paz con Vytautas, Jogaila entregó el trono de Lituania a él. Sin embargo, Vytautas seguido de Lituania a la demanda de separación de Polonia. Más tarde, después de haber sido aplastada por la Timurids en una batalla, Vytautas se vio obligado a ceder a la protección Jogaila una vez más. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En 1399, Jadwiga murió al dar a luz, dejando Jogaila el único gobernante de Polonia sin un heredero. En 1401, Vytautas fue reconocido como Gran Duque bajo Jogaila del overlordship, permitiendo también que los herederos de Jogaila, en lugar de los de Vytautas, para tener éxito al trono. Si los herederos no han nacido, el lituano boyars elegirá un nuevo monarca. Este acto forjado una alianza entre Polonia y Lituania, otro tanto para el fortalecimiento de la guerra contra la Orden Teutónica. Sin embargo, después de los problemas dentro de las fronteras, Jogaila fue derrotada después de una guerra con la Orden Teutónica, y dio a sus demandas. En 1408, y Jogaila Vytautas celebró conversaciones estratégicas en Navahrudak, donde se decidió a la revuelta contra la norma Teutónica en porciones de Lituania. La Orden declarado la guerra contra Polonia en el mismo año. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Los castillos en la frontera norte fueron fácilmente capturados por la Teutónica caballeros, y ambas partes prepararon para un importante enfrentamiento que el invierno. Ambas partes recibieron el apoyo de varios países europeos. Sin embargo, después de una de las mayores y más feroces batallas de la Edad Media, Jogaila y su ejército fueron vencedores. Jogaila, sin embargo, dudaban a la hora de pasar a la capital de Marienburg, y, por tanto, sufrió una pérdida en la ciudad. La guerra terminó en 1411 en el que ni Polonia ni Lituania volvió a casa con la totalidad de lo que espera ganar. Lituania recuperó gran parte de su territorio después de la guerra, pero el pueblo polaco comenzó a reactivar su desconfianza de Jogaila. Jogaila hecho varios intentos de fortalecer sus relaciones con el pueblo polaco, incluida la formación de una unión permanente entre Polonia y Lituania. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Una nueva guerra entre los Caballeros y Polonia, pero terminó en la nada, ya que ambas partes estaban todavía desgastado de la última guerra. Jogaila sigue siendo cuestión y escandalizó por su pueblo, y la pérdida de la popularidad que una vez tuvieron. En 1422, luchó Jogaila otra guerra contra la Orden Teutónica, derrotando a ellos en menos de dos meses. Más esporádicas guerras estalló entre Polonia y los Caballeros entre 1431 y 1435. Jogaila murió en 1434, dejando a Polonia a su hijo mayor y Lituania a su más joven, ambos menores de edad en el momento.

TEXT.English: [H1]Kamehameha the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Hawaii[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]1758 - 1819[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kamehameha's birth is surrounded by legend, and it is said that the Hawaiians claimed that a great king would one day unite the islands, and a comet would be the sign of his birth. When Kamehameha was born, Halley's Comet was visible in Hawaii. Kamehameha's birth name was Pai'ea, and he was born to Keku'iapoiwa, chief of the Kohala on the island of Hawai'i, and to Keoua. Keoua, his father, was the son of Keaweikekahiali'iokamoku, who was the chief of a large portion of Hawai'i. However, after his reign a war over succession broke, and Alapa'i emerged victorious over his brothers and their sons, including Keoua. When Kamehameha was born, Alapa'i ordered that he be killed, and was nervous at the thought that the child might eventually rule over Hawai'i. So, Kamehameha was given to another noble, Nae'ole, and thus disappeared from sight. Alapa'i, in remorse for his actions, invited the child to live in the royal court. [PARAGRAPH: 1] When Alapa'i died, he was succeeded by his son Keawea'opala who was challenged by Kalani'opu'u, Alapa'i's great nephew, and was backed by Kamehameha. At a battle at Kealakekua Bay, Keawea'opala was victorious and made Kamehameha his aid. In 1779, on a trip with Kalani'opu'u to Kealakekua Bay, Kamehameha met Captain Cook. Cook was mistaken to be the Hawaiian god of fertility, Lono, and Kamehameha may have been onboard his ship for some time. After Kalani'opu'u's death, kingship was inherited by his son Kiwala'o. Kamehameha was still given a prominent position, but there was a conflict between the two cousins. When a group of chiefs offered Kamehameha the kingship instead of Kiwala'o, he accepted and later defeated Kiwala'o at the Battle of Moku'ohai. [PARAGRAPH: 1] In 1790, Kamehameha deposed the chief of the district of Puna, Keawema'uhili. At the same time Keoua, exiled to his home, led an uprising. However, a third of his warriors were killed when he fled from the returning Kamehameha past a volcano. Kamehameha built a temple to sacrifice Keoua later, so that Kamehameha became the chief of all of Hawai'i. Kamehameha had other ambitions, and sought the help from British and American traders, who sold guns and ammunition to Kamehameha. When Kamehameha invaded the weakened islands of Maui and O'ahu, he did not think that his rival, Kalanikupule, also possessed firearms. [PARAGRAPH: 1] In 1795, Kamehameha set sail with an astonishing 1,200 war canoes and 10,000 soldiers. He quickly captured the islands of Maui and Moloka'i, and then moved on to O'ahu. However, one of Kamehameha's best commanders defected to Kalanikupule. In a series of skirmishes, Kamehameha and his army pushed back Kalanukupule until he was trapped. After Kamehameha's troops faced heavy cannon fire advancing to Kalanikupule, he sent his best warriors to attack the cannons from behind, which proved to be successful. Thus, Kalanikupule's troops fell into disarray and were defeated, with Kalanikupule being sacrificed later. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha was now the complete ruler of all of Hawai'i east of O'ahu, but the islands of Kaua'i and Ni'ihau were continuously escaping him. Kamehameha's first invasion was unsuccessful, and his second resulted in disease. After being intimidated by Kamehameha's new strong army, Kaumali'i, chief of Kaua'i, agreed to become a vassal of Kamehameha. As the first king of Hawaii, Kamehameha made several steps to make certain that the islands remained united after his death. He unified the legal system and didn't allow non-Hawaiians to own land. This proclamation guaranteed the islands' independence while other islands in the Pacific gave in to colonial authority. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha also instituted the Mamalohoe Kanawi, the Law of the Splintered Paddle. This law had origins in Kamehameha's early battles. The Law provided the safety of noncombatants during wartime, and remains in Hawaii's state constitution today, being its first law. When Kamehameha died in 1819, his body was trusted to his friend, Haopili. To this day, his resting place remains unknown.
TEXT.French: [H1]Kamehameha le Grand[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Roi de Hawaii[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates : [\BOLD]1758 - 1819[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kamehameha la naissance est entourée de légende, et il est dit que les Hawaïens affirmé qu'un grand roi serait un jour unir les îles, et une comète serait le signe de sa naissance. Quand Kamehameha est né, la comète de Halley était visible à Hawaii. Kamehameha le nom de naissance était Pai'ea, et il est né à Keku'iapoiwa, chef de la Kohala sur l'île de Hawaii, et à Keoua. Keoua, son père, était le fils de Keaweikekahiali'iokamoku, qui était le chef d'une grande partie de Hawai'i. Cependant, après son règne sur une guerre de succession a éclaté, et Alapa'i sorti vainqueur de ses frères et leurs fils, dont Keoua. Quand naquit Kamehameha, Alapa'i ordonné qu'il soit tué, mais était nerveux à l'idée que l'enfant pourrait finalement régner sur Hawai'i. Donc, Kamehameha a été donnée à un autre nobles, Nae'ole, et donc perdue de vue. Alapa'i, dans le remords de ses actes, a invité les enfants à vivre dans la cour royale. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Quand Alapa'i est mort, il a été remplacé par son fils Keawea'opala qui a été contestée par Kalani'opu'u, Alapa'i grand neveu, et a été appuyée par le Kamehameha. Lors d'une bataille à Kealakekua Bay, Keawea'opala a été victorieuse et fait Kamehameha son aide. En 1779, lors d'un voyage avec Kalani'opu'u à Kealakekua Bay, Kamehameha rencontré Captain Cook. Cook s'est trompé à l'hawaiien dieu de la fertilité, Lono, et Kamehameha peut avoir été à bord de son navire pendant un certain temps. Après Kalani'opu'u la mort, la royauté a été hérité par son fils Kiwala'o. Kamehameha était toujours donné une place importante, mais il y avait un conflit entre les deux cousins. Quand un groupe de chefs offert Kamehameha la royauté au lieu de Kiwala'o, il a accepté, puis battu Kiwala'o lors de la bataille de Moku'ohai. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En 1790, Kamehameha destitué le chef du district de Puna, Keawema'uhili. Dans le même temps Keoua, exilé à son domicile, a conduit un soulèvement. Cependant, un tiers de ses guerriers ont été tués quand il a fui le revenant Kamehameha passé d'un volcan. Kamehameha construit un temple à sacrifier Keoua plus tard, afin que Kamehameha est devenu le chef de l'ensemble de Hawai'i. Kamehameha avait d'autres ambitions, et a sollicité l'aide de la part des commerçants britanniques et américains, qui a vendu des fusils et des munitions à Kamehameha. Quand Kamehameha envahi les îles de Maui affaibli et O'ahu, il ne pensait pas que son rival, Kalanikupule, possédaient aussi des armes à feu. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En 1795, Kamehameha embarqua avec une étonnante 1200 guerre canots et 10000 soldats. Il a rapidement capturé les îles de Maui et Moloka'i, ensuite dirigé vers O'ahu. Toutefois, l'un des meilleurs commandants Kamehameha défection à Kalanikupule. Dans une série d'escarmouches, Kamehameha et son armée repoussé Kalanukupule jusqu'à ce qu'il ait été pris au piège. Ainsi, Kalanikupule troupes tombé dans le désarroi et l'ont battu, avec Kalanikupule sacrifié plus tard. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha était désormais la règle complète de l'ensemble des Hawai'i est du O'ahu, mais les îles de Kaua'i et Ni'ihau étaient continuellement lui échapper. Kamehameha la première invasion a échoué, et sa seconde conduit à la maladie. Après avoir été intimidés par Kamehameha la nouvelle armée forte, Kaumali'i, chef de Kaua'i, a accepté de devenir un vassal de Kamehameha. Comme le premier roi d'Hawai'i, Kamehameha fait plusieurs mesures pour s'assurer que les îles restent unies après sa mort. Il a unifié le système juridique et ne permet pas non Hawaïens de posséder des terres. Cette annonce garantit les îles' indépendance, alors que d'autres îles dans le Pacifique a donné à l'autorité coloniale. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha également institué des Mamalohoe Kanawi, le droit de la Splintered Paddle. Cette loi a Kamehameha origines dans le début des combats. La loi prévoit la sécurité des non-combattants en temps de guerre, et reste à Hawaii's Constitution de l'Etat aujourd'hui, étant sa première loi. Quand Kamehameha est mort en 1819, son corps a été digne de confiance à son ami, Haopili. À ce jour, son lieu de repos ne reste inconnu.
TEXT.German: [H1]Kamehameha der Große[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]König von Hawaii[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte: [\BOLD]1758 - 18190[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kamehameha Geburt ist umgeben von Legenden, und es wird gesagt, dass die Hawaiianer behauptet, dass ein großer König eines Tages vereinen die Inseln, und einem Kometen wäre das Zeichen seiner Geburt. Wenn Kamehameha wurde geboren, Halley's Comet wurde in Hawaii. Kamehameha Geburt war Pai'ea, und er war geboren zu Keku'iapoiwa, Chef der Kohala auf der Insel Hawaii, und Keoua. Keoua, sein Vater, der Sohn des Keaweikekahiali'iokamoku, der als Chef eines großen Teils von Hawaii. Aber nach seiner Herrschaft ein Krieg über Nachfolge brach, und Alapa'i den Sieg über seinen Brüdern und ihren Söhnen, einschließlich Keoua. Wenn Kamehameha wurde geboren, Alapa'i ordneten an, dass er getötet werden, wurde aber nervös bei dem Gedanken, dass das Kind vielleicht auch Herrschaft über Hawaii. Also, Kamehameha wurde auf einen anderen edlen, Nae'ole, und so verschwand aus dem Blick. Alapa'i, in der Reue für seine Taten, forderte das Kind auf ein Leben in der königlichen Gericht. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Wenn Alapa'i starb, wurde er Nachfolger seines Sohnes Keawea'opala, wurde von Kalani'opu'u, Alapa'i große Neffe, und wurde von Kamehameha. Bei der Schlacht bei Kealakekua Bay, Keawea'opala war siegreich und machte Kamehameha seine Hilfe. In 1779, auf einer Reise mit Kalani'opu'u zu Kealakekua Bay, Kamehameha traf Captain Cook. Cook war irre zu werden, die hawaiianische Gott der Fruchtbarkeit, Lono und Kamehameha Mai wurden an Bord seines Schiffes für einige Zeit. Nach Kalani'opu'u Tod, Königtum wurde geerbt von seinem Sohn Kiwala'o. Kamehameha war immer noch eine herausragende Stellung, aber es war ein Konflikt zwischen den beiden Vettern. Wenn eine Gruppe von Chefs angeboten Kamehameha das Königtum statt Kiwala'o, er akzeptiert, und später besiegt Kiwala'o in der Schlacht von Moku'ohai. [PARAGRAPH: 1] In 1790, Kamehameha abgesetzt, der Chef des Bezirks Puna, Keawema'uhili. Gleichzeitig Keoua, ins Exil zu seinem Haus, führte ein Aufstand. Aber ein Drittel seiner Krieger getötet wurden, wenn er floh aus der Vergangenheit zurückkehren Kamehameha ein Vulkan. Kamehameha ein Tempel zu opfern Keoua später, so dass Kamehameha wurde der Chef der von Hawaii. Kamehameha hatte andere Ambitionen, und suchte die Hilfe von britischen und amerikanischen Händlern, die verkauft Waffen und Munition zu Kamehameha. Wenn Kamehameha Invasion der Schwächung der Inseln Maui und O'ahu er nicht der Meinung, dass seine Rivalen, Kalanikupule, auch Schusswaffen besaß. [PARAGRAPH: 1] In 1795, Kamehameha die Segel mit einem erstaunlichen 1200 Krieg Kanus und 10000 Soldaten. Er eroberte schnell die Inseln Maui und Moloka'i, und wechselte dann auf O'ahu. Aber, einer der besten Kommandeure Kamehameha abtrünnig zu Kalanikupule. In einer Reihe von Scharmützeln, Kamehameha und seine Armee nach hinten Kalanukupule, bis er gefangen war. Nach Kamehameha's Truppen vor schweren Kanone Feuer voran zu Kalanikupule, schickte er seine besten Krieger zum Angriff gegen die Kanonen von hinten, die sich als erfolgreich. So Kalanikupule Truppen fiel in Unordnung und wurden besiegt, mit Kalanikupule geopfert später. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha wurde nun die vollständige Herrscher aller Hawaii östlich von O'ahu, aber die Inseln Kaua'i und Ni'ihau wurden kontinuierlich ihm zu entkommen. Kamehameha der ersten Invasion war nicht erfolgreich, und seine zweite führte in der Krankheit. Nach der eingeschüchtert von Kamehameha's neues starken Armee, Kaumali'i, Chef von Kaua'i, stimmte zu einem Vasallenstaat von Kamehameha. Da der erste König von Hawaii, Kamehameha mehrere Schritte, um sicherzustellen, dass die Inseln blieb vereint nach seinem Tod. Er vereinheitlichte das Rechtssystem und nicht erlauben nicht zu Hawaiianer eigenen Land. Diese Proklamation garantiert den Inseln die Unabhängigkeit, während die anderen Inseln im Pazifik hat in der Kolonialzeit Behörde. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha Darüber hinaus wurde die Mamalohoe Kanawi, das Recht der Splintered Rudern. Dieses Gesetz hatte Kamehameha Ursprung in der frühen Schlachten. Das Gesetz, die die Sicherheit der noncombatants in Kriegszeiten, und bleibt auf Hawaii die staatliche Verfassung heute, die ihre erste Gesetz. Wenn Kamehameha starb 1819, sein Körper war vertrauter zu seinem Freund, Haopili. Zu diesem Tag, seine Ruhestätte bleibt unbekannt.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Kamehameha il Grande[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Re di Hawaii[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vita: [\BOLD]1758 - 1819[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Informazioni:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kamehameha la nascita è circondato da leggenda, e si dice che il hawaiani sosteneva che un grande re sarebbe un giorno unire le isole, e una cometa sarebbe il segno della sua nascita. Kamehameha quando è nato, la cometa di Halley era visibile nelle Hawaii. Kamehameha la nascita nome era Pai'ea, ed egli è nato per Keku'iapoiwa, capo della Kohala sull'isola di Hawaii, e di Keoua. Keoua, suo padre, è stato il figlio di Keaweikekahiali'iokamoku, che era il capo di una grossa porzione di Hawai'i. Tuttavia, dopo il suo regno su una guerra di successione rotto, e Alapa'i uscito vittorioso oltre i suoi fratelli e dei loro figli, tra cui Keoua. Quando è nato Kamehameha, Alapa'i ordinato che egli essere ucciso, ma è stato nervoso al pensiero che il bambino potrebbe eventualmente dominerà Hawai'i. Così, Kamehameha è stato assegnato a un altro nobile, Nae'ole e, quindi, è scomparso dalla vista. Alapa'i, nel rimorso per le sue azioni, ha invitato il bambino a vivere in corte reale. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Quando Alapa'i morto, è stato succeduto da suo figlio Keawea'opala che è stato contestato da Kalani'opu'u, Alapa'i grande nipote, ed è stato sostenuto da Kamehameha. Nel corso di una battaglia a Kealakekua Bay, Keawea'opala è stato vittorioso e reso Kamehameha suo aiuto. Nel 1779, su un viaggio con Kalani'opu'u a Kealakekua Bay, Kamehameha incontrato il capitano Cook. Cook, è stato scambiato per il dio della fertilità hawaiano, Lono, Kamehameha e può essere stato per la sua nave a bordo di un po 'di tempo. Dopo Kalani'opu'u la morte, regalità è stata ereditata dal figlio Kiwala'o. Kamehameha è stato ancora dato un posto di rilievo, ma non vi è stato un conflitto tra i due cugini. Quando un gruppo di capi offerti Kamehameha la regalità invece di Kiwala'o, ha accettato e poi sconfitto Kiwala'o nella battaglia di Moku'ohai. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Nel 1790, Kamehameha deposto il capo del distretto di Puna, Keawema'uhili. Allo stesso tempo Keoua, in esilio a casa sua, ha condotto una rivolta. Tuttavia, un terzo dei suoi guerrieri sono stati uccisi quando fuggì dal ritorno Kamehameha passato un vulcano. Kamehameha costruito un tempio a sacrificare Keoua più tardi, in modo che Kamehameha divenne il capo di tutte le Hawaii. Kamehameha aveva altre ambizioni, e ha chiesto l'aiuto dei commercianti britannici e americani, che hanno venduto armi e munizioni a Kamehameha. Quando Kamehameha invaso il indebolito isole di Maui e O'ahu, egli non pensa che il suo rivale, Kalanikupule, possedeva armi da fuoco. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Nel 1795, Kamehameha salpare con un sorprendente 1200 guerra canoe e 10000 soldati. Egli ha rapidamente catturato le isole di Maui e Moloka'i, e poi passati alla O'ahu. Tuttavia, uno dei migliori comandanti Kamehameha disertavano a Kalanikupule. In una serie di scaramucce, e il suo esercito Kamehameha spinto indietro Kalanukupule fino a che non è stata intrappolata. Dopo Kamehameha le truppe di fronte pesante cannone fuoco avanzando a Kalanikupule, che ha inviato le sue migliori guerrieri di attaccare i cannoni da dietro, che si è rivelato efficace. Così, Kalanikupule truppe cadde in caos e sono stati respinti, con Kalanikupule essere sacrificati dopo. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha era ormai completo principe di tutti Hawai'i est di O'ahu, ma le isole di Kaua'i e Ni'ihau sono stati continuamente in fuga lui. Kamehameha la prima invasione è stata infruttuosa, e il suo secondo risultato malattia. Dopo essere stato intimidito da Kamehameha c'è di nuovo forte esercito, Kaumali'i, capo della Kaua'i, ha accettato di diventare un vassallo di Kamehameha. Come il primo re di Hawai'i, Kamehameha compiuti diversi passi per rendere certo che le isole sono rimasti uniti dopo la sua morte. Egli ha unificato il sistema giuridico e non ha consentito non hawaiani al possesso della terra. Questo annuncio garantite le isole 'indipendenza, mentre le altre isole del Pacifico ha dato al potere coloniale. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha anche istituito il Mamalohoe Kanawi, il diritto del Splintered Paddle. Questa legge ha avuto origine nel Kamehameha's prime battaglie. La legge prevedeva la sicurezza dei noncombatants durante il tempo di guerra, e resta in Hawaii costituzione dello stato di oggi, essendo la sua prima legge. Quando Kamehameha morì nel 1819, il suo corpo è stato confidato al suo amico, Haopili. Per questo giorno, il suo luogo di riposo rimane sconosciuto.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Kamehameha El Grande[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Rey de Hawái[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió: [\BOLD]1758 - 1819[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Historia:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kamehameha del nacimiento está rodeado de leyenda, y se dice que los hawaianos afirmó que un gran rey un día unir a las islas, y un cometa sería el signo de su nacimiento. Cuando nació Kamehameha, Cometa Halley fue visible en Hawaii. Kamehameha de nacimiento del nombre fue Pai'ea, y que nació a Keku'iapoiwa, jefe de la Kohala en la isla de Hawai, y para Keoua. Keoua, su padre, era hijo de Keaweikekahiali'iokamoku, que era el jefe de una gran parte de Hawai'i. Sin embargo, después de su reinado una guerra por la sucesión se rompió, y Alapa'i salido victorioso más de sus hermanos y sus hijos, incluyendo Keoua. Cuando nació Kamehameha, Alapa'i ordenó que se le mató, pero fue nervioso al pensar que el niño pueda llegar a la regla más de Hawai'i. Así, Kamehameha fue entregado a otra nobles, Nae'ole, y por lo tanto desapareció de la vista. Alapa'i, en el remordimiento por sus acciones, invitó a los niños a vivir en la corte real. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Cuando Alapa'i murió, fue sucedido por su hijo Keawea'opala que fue impugnado por Kalani'opu'u, Alapa'i del gran sobrino, y fue respaldado por Kamehameha. En una batalla en la bahía de Kealakekua, Keawea'opala fue victorioso e hizo Kamehameha su ayuda. En 1779, en un viaje con Kalani'opu'u a Kealakekua Bay, Kamehameha se reunió el capitán Cook. Cook se equivocaba al ser el Hawaiian dios de la fertilidad, Lono, y Kamehameha puede haber sido a bordo de su barco durante algún tiempo. Después de Kalani'opu'u de la muerte, la monarquía fue heredado por su hijo Kiwala'o. Kamehameha fue dado todavía una posición destacada, pero hay un conflicto entre los dos primos. Cuando un grupo de jefes ofrecido Kamehameha la monarquía en lugar de Kiwala'o, aceptó y más tarde derrotó Kiwala'o en la Batalla de Moku'ohai. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En 1790, Kamehameha depuesto el jefe del distrito de Puna, Keawema'uhili. Al mismo tiempo Keoua, exiliado a su casa, llevó un levantamiento. Sin embargo, un tercio de sus guerreros fueron muertos cuando huían de la repatriación de Kamehameha pasado de un volcán. Kamehameha construido un templo a sacrificar Keoua más tarde, de manera que Kamehameha se convirtió en el jefe de todos los de Hawai'i. Kamehameha tenía otras ambiciones, y solicitó la ayuda de los comerciantes británicos y americanos, que vendieron armas y municiones a Kamehameha. Cuando Kamehameha invadido el debilitamiento de las islas de Maui y O'ahu, no cree que su rival, Kalanikupule, también poseen armas de fuego. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En 1795, Kamehameha zarpó con un asombroso 1200 la guerra canoas y 10000 soldados. Rápidamente capturados en las islas de Maui y Moloka'i, y luego se trasladó a O'ahu. Sin embargo, uno de los mejores comandantes de Kamehameha desertado a Kalanikupule. En una serie de escaramuzas, y su ejército Kamehameha aplazado Kalanukupule hasta que fue atrapado. Después de las tropas de Kamehameha enfrentan pesados cañones fuego avanza a Kalanikupule, envió sus mejores guerreros para atacar por detrás de los cañones, lo que resultó ser un éxito. Así, Kalanikupule las tropas cayó en desorden y fueron derrotados, con Kalanikupule ser sacrificado más tarde. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Kamehameha se completa ahora el gobernante de la totalidad de Hawai'i este de O'ahu, pero las islas de Kaua'i y Ni'ihau fueron continuamente escapar de él. Kamehameha la primera invasión no fue exitosa, y su segundo resultado en la enfermedad.
